text: soldiers everywhere in a change welcomed
by many residents of Basra the Iraqi
troops began to crack down on the
southern cities militias in March and
tentatively it is working this southern
port is Iraq's gateway to the Persian
Gulf and beneath the ground as a huge
amount of Iraq soil that oil leaky
borders with Iran and a decades-old
smuggling racket makes it a paradise for
criminals for years Shiite militias have
preyed on the population Sunnis and
Shiites alike killing intimidating
forcing women to wear what they decree
enforcing men to do what they want but
now on the streets and in the markets
people are more relaxed stores are
staying open later at night women
academics and musicians all say the
death squads and morality enforcers are
now off the streets allowing them to
breathe more freely Prime Minister Nuri
Kamel al Maliki has placed more than
30,000 Iraqi soldiers and police in the
city at checkpoints and on highways
Humvees tanks and armored cars patrol
the streets occasionally American
Humvees and British armored vehicles can
be seen but Iraqi troops and Iraqi
bullets make up a majority of the
military presence the Iraqi military has
taken control of the militias
headquarters graffiti outside the
building now reads yes yes to Maliki
Iraqi troops have arrested militia
suspects in seized weapons mortars
machine guns roadside bombs and even
they say the booby-trapped baby carriage
the prayer hall used by extremists has
been cleared
partially torn down despite the gains
the face of moqtada al-sadr the leader
of the Maquis army is still on the
streets the fight only ended after a
deal and he still has a large following
political and military many Basra wees
believe that the death squads may simply
outweigh the temporarily reinforced
Iraqi troops the poverty in resentment
here provide excellent recruiting tools
for the militias in some areas
Fighting's what they know first and best
sad rests say the military operation is
simply an effort to weaken the Prime
Minister's Shiite rivals ahead of
provincial elections in October an
observation balloon above the British
headquarters at buzzer airport
a rocket attack two people dead eight
wounded
they were the first casualties in more
than a month but that was no consolation
to their families
not all clear in basra not yet
